A few years ago, while getting ready for bed on a Thanksgiving night, my father fell and fractured his hip. I drove to meet him in the emergency room, where the young woman at the front desk looked up at me and said, blandly, “You must be here to see Room 4.” I was actually there to see my dad, but resisted the opportunity to make that a teachable moment and headed to room 4. When I walked in, the nurse was standing with her hand on my dad’s shoulder. She greeted me warmly and started sharing “what a cool guy” my father is, that he must be in a lot of pain but has been joking and making her laugh, that he’s been telling her about being with the family for Thanksgiving and even about my work in healthcare.

The Glasgow Consensus Statement – published last week and available at https://lnkd.in/ebr7dJXu – focuses on reinforcing the humanity in healthcare. The primary overarching task is to Connect as Humans. That’s the difference between ‘room 4’ and ‘what a cool guy’. Human connection is essential, not extra. And it benefits patients, families, and health professionals – I hope we can all rally around that.

We must strive for sustainability in everything we do, making sure that our advancements in CX and AI don't come at the cost of our environment.This photo, from the top of the world, is a reminder to me.
